natural solution: The value $x=f^{-1}(-31/96)$ is the solution to $f(x)=-31/96$. This means \[\frac{x^5-1}3=\frac{-31}{96}.\]Multiplying by 3 gives \[x^5-1=\frac{-31}{32}.\]If we add 1 we get  \[x^5=\frac{-31}{32}+\frac{32}{32}=\frac1{32},\]and the only value that solves this equation is  \[x=\boxed{\frac12}.\]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x powr 5 - 1) / 3"
and h2 : "f (inv f (-31 / 96)) = -31 / 96"
shows  "inv f (-31 / 96) = 1 / 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x powr 5 - 1) / 3"

shows  "inv f (-31 / 96) = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
